To learn which actions are required for a given data operation, see Permissions for calling data operations. Storage Queue Data Reader Read and list Azure Storage queues and queue messages. To learn which actions are required for a given data operation, see Permissions for calling data operations. Storage Table Data Contributor Allows for read, write and delete access to Azure Storage tables and entities. Storage Table Data Reader Allows for read access to Azure Storage tables and entities. Cognitive Services OpenAI User Read access to view files, models, deployments. The ability to create completion and embedding calls.
info Azure RBAC Documentation: Learn more about Azure RBAC Azure Built-in Roles Complete Guide: View built-in roles Assign Azure Roles Using Portal: How to assign roles via the portal
documents.s: How to use Azure RBAC Roles

documents.t: Azure Tags are metadata elements that you can apply to Azure resources such as virtual machines, storage accounts and resource groups, etc.  Tags consist of key-value pairs that help you organize, manage and track resources across your Azure environment.  By tagging resources, you can easily identify, categorize and filter resources based on specific criteria.

Deciding Factors Reason Resource Organization Use tags to categorize resources by department, project, environment (e.g., production, development, staging). Cost Management Tags help track and allocate costs by tagging resources with cost-related information, making it easier to generate reports and manage budgets. Automation Tags can be used to automate resource management tasks. For example, use tags to identify resources that should be backed up or shut down during off-hours. Compliance and Governance Tags help ensure compliance with organizational policies by providing a way to enforce tagging standards across your resources. Filtering and Reporting Tags allow you to filter and generate reports on specific groups of resources based on tags, making it easier to manage large environments.
info Azure Tags Documentation: Learn more about Azure Tags How to Apply Tags via Portal: How to Apply Tags via Portal Using Azure Policy to Enforce Tags: Using Azure Policy to Enforce Tags

A Private Endpoint in Azure is a network interface that connects privately and securely to an Azure service by using Azure Private Link.  It enables access to Azure services, such as Azure Storage, Azure SQL Database and custom services, over a private IP address within a virtual network (VNet). This eliminates the need for data to traverse the public internet, enhancing security and reducing exposure to external threats.

Deciding Factors Reason Example Securing Sensitive Data Use Private Endpoints to secure access to Azure services that handle sensitive or confidential data, ensuring that all traffic remains within your private network and doesnt traverse the public internet. Access a sensitive Azure SQL Database that contains financial data through a Private Endpoint, blocking any public access. Minimizing Exposure to the Public Internet Use Private Endpoints to reduce the attack surface of your Azure services by disabling public access and ensuring that only authorized users within your VNet can access the service. Connect to an Azure Storage account that stores critical business files via a Private Endpoint to prevent public internet access. Reducing Latency Use Private Endpoints to reduce latency by routing traffic directly through Azures private backbone network rather than through the public internet. Access a geographically distant Azure Storage account with lower latency by using a Private Endpoint.
info Learn more about Azure Private Link Documentation  Learn more about Creating a private endpoint by using the Azure portal

Identity management is a critical aspect of securing and managing access to resources in Azure. This section covers the various tools and features to manage identities, control access and enforce security policies. info Identity management in Microsoft Entra ID will be handled mostly by the Organization IT Team. The following section highlights the Entra ID security best practices.

Microsoft Entra ID, formerly Azure Active Directory (Azure AD), is a cloud-based identity and access management service. It helps users to sign in and access resources in the Azure portal. Use Microsoft Entra ID Connect to synchronize on-premises Active Directory with Microsoft Entra ID. Enable Entra MFA authentication to add an additional layer of security by requiring users to provide a second form of authentication, such as a security code or time-based passwords. Enable Conditional Access to automate control decisions based on conditions (who, what, circumstances) and controls (MFA, block access, device compliance). Enforce Entra ID Password Protection to detect and block weak passwords. Implement Privileged Identity Management (PIM) service to manage, control and monitor access to important resources in your organization. Use Microsoft Entra ID Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to manage access to Entra ID resources. Follow the least-privilege principle for RBAC roles. Enable Microsoft Entra self-service password reset (SSPR) to allow users to change or reset their password without the administrator or help desk. Enable SSO (Single Sign-On) to allow users to sign in once to access multiple applications and services without re-entering credentials. Enable Identity Protection to automate the detection and remediation of identity-based risks using machine learning and intelligence. Use Entra ID audit logs to get comprehensive reports on every logged event.

Factors Service Endpoint Private Endpoint Network Security Extends VNet identity to Azure services, securing access over Azure's backbone network. Provides private access to Azure services via a private IP address, completely isolated from the internet. Access and Connectivity Accesses Azure services using public IP, but routes traffic securely within Azure's network. Accesses Azure services using a private IP from the VNet, with no public IP exposure. Configuration and Management Easier to configure, no DNS changes required, uses public endpoints. Requires more configuration, including DNS updates and uses private IP addresses. Public Endpoint Exposure Public endpoints remain accessible unless explicitly restricted. Public endpoint can be completely disabled, enhancing security. Use Case Ideal for securing access while maintaining public endpoint flexibility. Ideal for scenarios requiring maximum security, privacy and isolation from the public internet.

Governance in Azure refers to the set of processes, policies and guidelines used to ensure that an organizations use of Azure resources aligns with its strategic goals, regulatory requirements and best practices. It involves: Maintaining Security  Ensuring Compliance  Managing Risks  Controlling Costs  Enabling Efficient Operations

Establishes rules and policies to protect sensitive data and meet regulatory requirements. Helps maintain a secure environment by enforcing security practices such as access controls, encryption and monitoring. Helps control and optimize spending in Azure by setting budgets, tracking resource usage and avoiding unexpected expenses. Ensures efficient resource management by provisioning, managing and decommissioning resources effectively, avoiding wastage. Identifies potential risks related to the deployment and operation of resources in Azure and implements strategies to mitigate them. Ensures business continuity by implementing disaster recovery plans and safeguarding critical workloads.

Azure Virtual Network (VNet) is the fundamental block for private networking in Azure. It enables you to create a logically isolated network in the Azure cloud to securely connect and manage Azure resources.
Plan IP address spaces carefully, avoiding overlap with on-premises networks or other VNets. Use CIDR notation and ensure adequate IP ranges for future growth.
Ensure VNets are region-specific, avoiding cross-region dependencies to reduce latency and increase reliability.

A subnet (short for "subnetwork") is a smaller, segmented portion of a larger network, such as a Virtual Network (VNet) in Azure. Subnets help to organize and isolate resources within a network, allowing for more granular control over network traffic, security and management.

When you create a VNet, you define a range of IP addresses using CIDR (Classless Inter-Domain Routing) notation. You can then create multiple subnets within that VNet, each with its own subset of the VNet's IP address range. Resources, such as virtual machines, can be placed in different subnets, allowing you to manage and secure them independently.

Subnets are used to divide a VNet into multiple, smaller networks, each with its own IP address range. Resources within different subnets can be isolated from each other, depending on security and access requirements. Use subnets to logically group resources based on their function, role, or access needs (e.g., web servers, application servers, database servers). Example: You might place web servers in one subnet, application servers in another and databases in a third, each with different security and routing rules. Use subnets to apply different security controls to different parts of your network. Example: Place sensitive or critical resources in a subnet with stricter security controls. Use Network Security Groups (NSGs) to control inbound and outbound traffic for each subnet. Example: Restrict internet access to only a web-facing subnet while keeping backend databases in a more secure, isolated subnet.
info Azure subnet configuration documentation: Learn More Virtual Network: Learn More

Below are the best practices when it comes to subnet sizing and address space allocation for Azure Virtual Networks. Assess Requirements Determine Resource Needs: Evaluate the number of resources planned to deploy and their networking requirements. Consider Future Growth: Factor in potential future expansion to avoid frequent reconfiguration. Subnet Sizing Avoid Over-provisioning: Allocate only as many IP addresses as needed. Using large subnets (e.g., /24) for a few resources can lead to wasted IP space. Typical Subnet Sizes /25: 128 IP addresses (5 reserved by Azure, 123 usable). Suitable for larger subnets where you need more IP addresses space /26: 64 IP addresses (5 reserved by Azure, 59 usable). Suitable for smaller subnets where you need a limited number of IP addresses /27: 32 IP addresses (5 reserved by Azure, 27 usable). Suitable for small deployments. /28: 16 IP addresses (5 reserved by Azure, 11 usable). Ideal for very small deployments or dedicated services. Subnet Scope: Use smaller subnets for isolated or specialized environments and larger subnets where you expect higher density.

CIDR Block Allocation: Choose an address space large enough to accommodate current and future subnets but avoid excessive reservation. For instance, a /16 block provides 65,536 addresses, which might be excessive for a small number of subnets. Avoid Fragmentation: Plan address spaces to minimize fragmentation and maintain efficient IP management.

Small Project: For a project with fewer than 10 resources, consider using /26 or /27 subnet address space. Medium Project: For 20-50 resources, using multiple /26 or /25 subnet address space might be appropriate. Large Project: For larger deployments, plan subnet & address space sizes based on specific needs and future scalability.

Azure Resource IP Count App service 1 for private endpoint Storage Account 1 for Blob private endpoint 1 for Queue private endpoint 1 for Table private endpoint 1 for File private endpoint Total  4 Private IPs required Virtual Machine 1 for private endpoint or 1 for public IP (optional) Open AI Services 1 for private endpoint Application gateway 1 for public IP or 1 for private IP (In both cases the application gateway requires dedicated subnet) Virtual network Subnet Azure reserves the first four and last IP addresses in each subnet for internal use. Total Usable IP = Subnet Range - 5
documents.s: Azure Resources and Private IP Requirements

documents.t: Let's assume in a project you are using 4 app services, 1 storage account, 1 virtual machine & all resources are connected to a Virtual Network over a private endpoint. The number of IP addresses required will be Azure Resource IP Count Description App Service 1 private IP * 4 = 4 IP's Storage Account 4 private IPs Blob private endpoint: 1 Queue private endpoint: 1 Table private endpoint: 1 File private endpoint: 1 Virtual Machine 1 private IP Total Private IPs Needed: 9 private IP addresses. Subnet Sizing Azure reserves the first four and last IP addresses in each subnet for internal use. Therefore, the number of usable IP addresses in a subnet is the total IP addresses minus 5. Example Subnet Sizes /28 (16 total IPs, 11 usable) Total IP addresses: 16 Usable IP addresses: 11 Summary: Sufficient for this scenario (8 IPs needed). /27 (32 total IPs, 27 usable) Total IP addresses: 32 Usable IP addresses: 27 Summary: Provides additional IPs for future growth. You may want to leave some room for future expansion or additional resources, so a /27 subnet might be a safer choice for flexibility.

A Service Endpoint in Azure allows you to extend your Virtual Network (VNet) to include specific Azure services.  This means that you can securely connect to Azure services, like Azure Storage or Azure SQL Database, directly over the Azure backbone network without exposing your data to the public internet.

Deciding Factors Reason Example Enhancing Security for Azure Services Use Service Endpoints to secure access to Azure services by ensuring that traffic from your VNet to the service does not traverse the public internet. Connect to an Azure SQL Database from your VNet using a service endpoint to prevent data from being exposed to the public internet. Improving Latency and Performance Use Service Endpoints to improve performance and reduce latency by keeping traffic within Azures backbone network, avoiding the public internet. Reduce latency for an Azure App Service that relies heavily on data stored in Azure Storage by connecting them using a service endpoint. Using with Existing Public Endpoints Service Endpoints are beneficial when you want to maintain public endpoint access while ensuring secure traffic flow from your VNet. Allow public access to a web application hosted in Azure App Service while securing backend database access through a service endpoint.
info Learn more about Azure Service Endpoints Documentation

Application Security Groups (ASGs) simplifies the management of network security rules by allowing to group together virtual machines (VMs) with similar functions and apply security rules to those groups. This makes it easier to manage and enforce security policies without needing to maintain complex sets of IP addresses.
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/Networking/Security Groups/Application Security Group

documents.t: Deciding Factors Reason Simplifying Security Rule Management Use ASGs to simplify the management of security rules across multiple VMs. Dynamic and Scalable Environments In dynamic environments where VMs are frequently added or removed, ASGs are beneficial because security rules automatically apply to any VM added to the group, reducing the need for manual updates. Large-Scale Deployments In large-scale deployments where managing individual IP addresses becomes impractical, ASGs offer a scalable way to enforce consistent security policies across your infrastructure.
documents.s: When to use Application Security Group
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/Networking/Security Groups/Application Security Group

documents.t: info For comprehensive information on Application Security Groups (ASGs), please visit the official Microsoft documentation Application Security Groups Documentation
documents.s: How to use Application Security Group
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/Networking/Security Groups/Application Security Group

documents.t: A Network Security Group (NSG) is a allows to control inbound and outbound network traffic to and from resources by using security rules  It acts as a virtual firewall, enabling you to define and enforce security rules at the network level, ensuring that only permitted traffic is allowed for resources
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/Networking/Security Groups/Network Security Groups

documents.t: Rules Configuration NSGs contain security rules that define which types of traffic are allowed or denied based on various criteria, such as: Source and Destination: Specifies the IP addresses, ranges, or subnets where the traffic is coming from and where its going. Port: Specifies the port number or range that the traffic is targeting (e.g., HTTP on port 80, SSH on port 22). Protocol: Specifies the network protocol (e.g., TCP, UDP, ICMP) that the rule applies. Each rule has a priority, which determines the order in which the rules are processed. Lower numbers indicate higher priority. Assignment to Subnets and NICs NSGs can be associated with either subnets or individual network interfaces (NICs). When an NSG is applied to a subnet, the rules apply to all resources within that subnet. When applied to a NIC, the rules only apply to the associated resource (like VM). Inbound and Outbound Traffic Filtering Inbound Rules: Control incoming traffic to the resources within a VNet or subnet. Outbound Rules: Control outgoing traffic from the resources to other networks or the internet. The rules are evaluated in order of priority and the first rule that matches the traffic criteria is applied. Default Rules NSGs come with a set of default rules that allow basic network functionality (e.g., allowing VNet-to-VNet communication and outbound internet traffic). These default rules can be overridden by custom rules.
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/Networking/Security Groups/Network Security Groups

documents.t: Securing Subnets Use NSGs to apply security controls at the subnet level, ensuring that all resources within the subnet are protected by the same set of rules.  Example: Apply an NSG to a subnet that hosts web servers in VM to allow HTTP/HTTPS traffic from the internet but block all other traffic.  Isolating Network Tiers Use NSGs to enforce security boundaries between different tiers of an application (e.g., web, app, database) within a VNet.  Example: Apply an NSG to the application tier to allow traffic only from the web tier and block all direct access from the internet.  Managing Traffic to/from the Internet Use NSGs to control which resources can communicate with the internet, thereby reducing the attack surface and protecting sensitive data. Example: Apply an NSG to restrict outbound traffic from a database server to the internet, ensuring that it can only communicate with specific trusted services.
documents.s: When to use Network Security Group
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/Networking/Security Groups/Network Security Groups

documents.t: info For detailed information on Network Security Groups (NSGs), please refer to the official documentation provided by Microsoft Network Security Groups Documentation
documents.s: How to use Network Security Group
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/Networking/Security Groups/Network Security Groups

documents.t: VNet DDoS Protection in Azure is a service designed to protect your Azure Virtual Network (VNet) from Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks. DDoS attacks attempt to overwhelm and disrupt the availability of your network resources by flooding them with a massive volume of traffic. Azure offers two types of DDoS protection: Basic DDoS Protection: Automatically included with Azure services at no additional cost. It provides protection against common network-layer attacks. DDoS Protection Standard: An advanced, customizable offering that provides additional protection for your Azure resources against more sophisticated DDoS attacks.
documents.s: What is VNet DDoS Protection in Azure

documents.t: Deciding Factors Reason Example Protecting Public-Facing Applications Use DDoS Protection Standard to secure applications exposed to the internet, such as web applications, APIs, or public endpoints, which are more vulnerable to DDoS attacks. Protect a public-facing e-commerce website that handles sensitive transactions and needs to be available 24/7. Enhancing Security for Critical Services Use DDoS Protection Standard for mission-critical services that require high availability and cannot afford downtime caused by a DDoS attack. Apply DDoS protection to a financial application that processes real-time transactions for thousands of users. Cost Management for High-Volume Applications Use DDoS Protection Standard to prevent unexpected costs due to autoscaling or resource usage spikes during an attack, as it includes cost protection features. Protect a scalable video streaming service that could experience increased costs due to traffic surges caused by a DDoS attack.
documents.s: When to use VNet DDos Protection

documents.t: info Learn More about Azure DDOS protection Documentation
documents.s: How to use VNet DDOS protection

documents.t: Secrets Management refers to the process of securely storing, managing and accessing sensitive information such as API keys, passwords, tokens, certificates and other confidential data.  Protection The goal is to protect these secrets from unauthorized access while ensuring they are available to authorized applications and services when needed.  Security Effective secrets management is crucial for maintaining the security and integrity of applications.

Traditionally, secrets like tokens, API keys and passwords were embedded directly into application code, stored in configuration files or environment variables.  Security Risks This approach posed significant security risks, as secrets could easily be exposed through source code leaks, configuration mishandling or unauthorized access to the storage locations. Remediation with Azure Key Vault  To remediate this situation, we use Azure Key Vault to securely store and manage secrets, encryption keys and certificates.  Centralized Management Azure Key Vault provides a centralized and secure way to manage access to secrets, reducing the risks associated with hardcoding or manually managing sensitive information.  Access Management While developers can securely store the secrets in Azure Key Vault, services still need a way to access Azure Key Vault by using API Keys or tokens.

The recommended way for managing identity now is Azure Managed Identity Azure Managed Identity is a service that simplifies secrets management by automatically managing the identity for Azure resources, eliminating the need to store credentials in code. Managed Identity provides a secure and streamlined way for Azure services to authenticate to other services that support Entra ID (Azure AD) authentication.

Type Description System-Assigned Managed Identity Automatic Creation: Automatically created and managed by Azure for a specific single resource (e.g., a virtual machine or Azure function). Lifecycle Tied: The identity is tied to the lifecycle of the resource; it is created when the resource is created and deleted when the resource is deleted. Ideal Use: Ideal for scenarios where the identity is only needed for a specific resource and you want Azure to manage it automatically. User-Assigned Managed Identity Independent Creation: Created as an independent Azure resource that can be assigned to multiple Azure resources. Independent Lifecycle: The identity exists independently of the resources its assigned to, allowing for greater flexibility and reuse. Ideal Use: Useful when you need a consistent identity across multiple resources or want to manage the identity independently of the associated resources.

It is highly recommended that only Managed Identity be used for Azure resources. Use traditional methods such as tokens or API keys only when there is a specific, valid reason that Managed Identity cannot fulfill. Examples Legacy systems that do not support Entra ID authentication. Third-party services that require API keys.

info Learn about Managed Identity and how it simplifies secrets management for Azure resources Managed Identity Overview A guide on creating Managed Identities and using them in your code Creating and Using Managed Identity in Code How to use the Azure SDK Python package to work with Managed Identities Azure SDK Python Package

VNet Peering allows you to connect two or more Virtual Networks (VNets) so that they appear as a single network. Once peered, VNets can communicate with each other using private IP addresses, just as if they were part of the same network. VNet Peering creates a low-latency, high-bandwidth connection between VNets, making it useful for scenarios where resources in different VNets need to communicate efficiently and securely.

Deciding Factors Reason Example Cross-Region Communication Use VNet Peering when you need to enable communication between VNets in different regions for global applications. Connect VNets in the East US and West Europe regions to enable a globally distributed application. Hub-and-Spoke Network Architecture Use VNet Peering to implement a hub-and-spoke architecture, where a central VNet (hub) connects to multiple VNets (spokes), facilitating centralized management of resources like firewalls and gateways. Set up a hub VNet to manage security policies and connect to multiple spoke VNets. Improving Performance Use VNet Peering to reduce latency and improve performance for workloads that span multiple VNets within the same or different regions. Enhance the performance of a distributed application by peering VNets across regions.
info Learn more about Azure VNet Peering Documentation  Learn more about Connect VNets in Azure Portal
Implementing security best practices in Azure is crucial to protect cloud resources, data and applications from various threats. [In-Progress]
Azure VPN Gateway and Azure ExpressRoute are two different solutions provided by Azure to connect on-premises networks to Azure Virtual Networks (VNets) securely and efficiently.
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/VPN Gateway & Express Route

documents.t: Azure VPN Gateway is a service that enables you to create a secure, encrypted connection between your on-premises network and your Azure VNets over the public internet.
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/VPN Gateway & Express Route

documents.t: Deciding Factors Reason Small to Medium-Sized Deployments When you have smaller workloads or limited bandwidth requirements. Cost-Sensitive Scenarios When you need a secure connection but want to minimize costs. Remote Access Needs When you need to provide secure access to individual users or remote offices.
documents.s: When to use Azure VPN Gateway
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/VPN Gateway & Express Route

documents.t: Azure ExpressRoute is a dedicated, private connection between your on-premises infrastructure and Azure. Unlike VPN Gateway, ExpressRoute does not go over the public internet, but instead uses a private connection provided by a connectivity provider.
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/VPN Gateway & Express Route

documents.t: Deciding Factors Reason Large-Scale or Mission-Critical Deployments For enterprises with high-performance needs, such as financial institutions or healthcare organizations. High Bandwidth Requirements When you need to transfer large amounts of data between on-premises and Azure. Regulatory Compliance When regulatory requirements mandate that your traffic cannot traverse the public internet. Global Connectivity When you need to connect multiple global offices to Azure with high reliability and performance.
documents.s: When to use Azure Express Route
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/VPN Gateway & Express Route

documents.t: Factors Azure VPN Gateway Azure ExpressRoute Connection Type Over the public internet using encrypted tunnels. Private connection through a dedicated circuit. Performance Variable, dependent on internet traffic, generally lower bandwidth. High performance with low latency, higher and more consistent bandwidth. Security Secure via encryption (IPsec), but traffic goes over the public internet. Highly secure, private connection that does not traverse the public internet. Cost Generally lower cost, suitable for smaller budgets. Higher cost, suitable for enterprises with greater connectivity needs. Availability Dependent on internet stability and VPN Gateway performance. High availability with SLA-backed uptime, suitable for critical workloads. Use Case Small to medium-sized deployments, remote access, cost-sensitive scenarios. Large-scale, mission-critical applications, high bandwidth and low latency needs.
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/VPN Gateway & Express Route

documents.t: info Learn more about Azure VPN Gateway Documentation Learn more about Azure ExpressRoute Documentation
documents.s: How to use VPN Gateway or ExpressRoute
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Azure Security/VPN Gateway & Express Route

documents.t: Azure Cost Management is a suite of tools provided by Microsoft to help monitor, allocate and optimize the costs of your Azure services. It helps to understand where Azure spending is going, identifies cost-saving opportunities and enables you to stay within budget by offering real-time visibility and management of the Azure expenses.

Factors Description Budget Control Helps to set and enforce spending limits, ensuring you do not exceed your financial plans. Cost Optimization Identifies areas where to save money, such as underutilized resources or opportunities for discounts. Accountability Provides insights into which teams or departments are consuming resources, enabling better chargeback and accountability. Forecasting Assists in predicting future spending based on current usage trends, helping with budget planning and management.

Data Collection  Collects cost and usage data across all Azure resources in real-time. Cost Analysis  Provides detailed insights and analysis tools to understand spending patterns and trends. Includes breakdowns by service, region, resource group, or tags. Budgets and Alerts  Allows you to create budgets and receive alerts when costs approach or exceed the set limits. Cost Optimization  Suggests recommendations for cost savings, such as identifying underutilized resources, resizing the resources or providing reserved instance pricing options

Cost Analysis in Azure Portal  Use the Cost Analysis tool to view, analyze and understand your cost and usage data. Filter by subscriptions, resource groups, services, or specific tags to drill down into cost details. Azure Cost Alerts  Set cost alerts to receive notifications when spending reaches specific thresholds. Use these alerts to proactively manage costs and prevent overspending. Azure Advisor  Use Azure Advisor for personalized recommendations on cost optimization, such as resizing or shutting down idle resources. Azure Cost Management Reports  Generate custom cost and usage reports that can be shared with stakeholders. Use built-in reports or create custom ones using filters for specific services, tags, or time periods. Azure Pricing Calculator  Estimate the cost of your planned Azure architecture using the Azure Pricing Calculator. Adjust configurations, regions and services to understand the impact on cost.

Set Budgets  Create budgets for subscriptions or resource groups to define spending limits. Configure alerts to notify stakeholders or owners when spending approaches a certain percentage of the budget or exceeds the set budget. Use Azure Reservations  Purchase Azure Reservations for virtual machines, SQL databases, or other services to get significant discounts compared to pay-as-you-go pricing. Commit to a 1-year or 3-year term to maximize cost savings. Right-size Resources  Continuously monitor resource usage and identify underutilized or idle resources. Resize virtual machines, databases and other resources to match actual workloads. Leverage Azure Hybrid Benefit  Use existing on-premises licenses for Microsoft products, such as Windows Server and SQL Server, to reduce the costs of running them in Azure. Use Cost-effective Storage Tiers  Choose the appropriate storage tier (e.g., Hot, Cool, Archive) based on your access patterns and data retention requirements. Implement Automation  Use automation scripts or tools to start/stop resources based on usage patterns, such as shutting down non-production resources during off-hours. Monitor Data Transfer Costs  Minimize data transfer costs by placing resources in the same region and optimizing network architecture.

info Learn more about Azure Cost Management Documentation Learn more about Creating and managing budgets Learn more about Azure Pricing Calculator Learn more about Azure Advisor Recommendations Learn more about Azure Cost Management + Billing integration documentation
documents.s: How to Use Azure Cost Management

documents.t: Azure Network Watcher is a comprehensive network monitoring and diagnostics tool for managing and monitoring your Azure network resources. It provides a suite of tools that enable you to diagnose network connectivity issues, view metrics and log network traffic to improve the performance, security, and reliability of your network infrastructure in Azure.

Factors Reason Monitor and Diagnose Network Issues Continuously monitor your Azure network traffic and identify performance bottlenecks or connection failures. Analyze Network Security Use diagnostic tools like packet capture and flow logs to detect security anomalies or threats. Optimize Network Performance Gain insights into network latency and bandwidth, enabling informed decisions about resource scaling or topology changes. Maintain Compliance Keep track of network activity through detailed logging and reporting for regulatory compliance and audits.
documents.s: When to use Azure Network Watcher

documents.t: Understanding basic network traffic logging Monitoring network communication between two virtual machines Monitor network communication with a virtual machine scale set Diagnose a virtual machine network routing problem Diagnose a virtual machine network traffic filter problem Diagnose a virtual machine network traffic filter problem using Azure PowerShell Diagnose a virtual machine network traffic filter problem using the Azure CLI Diagnose a communication problem between virtual networks
documents.s: How to use Azure Network Watcher

documents.t: info Overview of Azure Network Watcher Azure Network Watcher
documents.s: Learn more about Azure Network Watcher

documents.t: cURL (Client URL) is a versatile command-line tool and library used for transferring data with URLs across various protocols, including HTTP, HTTPS, FTP and more. It enables users to send and receive data to and from servers, making it invaluable for tasks like API testing, file downloads, and website monitoring. With extensive customization options, cURL allows users to set headers, manage cookies, and handle authentication, making it ideal for both development and automation.
The curl command is the same for both Windows and Linux when performing a basic GET request. # Basic GET Request `curl https://google.com`

NSLookup.io and WhatsMyDNS.net are online tools that allow users to check and query DNS records for specific domains across multiple DNS servers worldwide. NSLookup.io enables users to query DNS records from various DNS servers, making it valuable for network administrators, web developers, and anyone needing to troubleshoot or analyze DNS settings for their domains or websites. WhatsMyDNS.net is particularly useful for diagnosing DNS propagation issues, ensuring that changes to DNS records are correctly reflected across different DNS servers globally. tip For more information and to check the DNS, visit WhatsMyDNS.net. For more information and to query DNS records for a domain name, visit NSLookup.io.

The URL chrome://net-internals/#dns in Google Chrome, edge://net-internals/#dns in Microsoft Edge and about:networking#dns in FireFox provides access to the browser's internal networking diagnostics and DNS settings. It allows users and developers to view detailed information about the DNS cache, including the currently cached DNS records and associated metadata. This tool is particularly useful for diagnosing DNS-related issues, such as connectivity problems or incorrect IP address resolution. Users can also manually clear the DNS cache from this interface, which can help resolve issues caused by stale or outdated DNS entries. The tool enables users to manually clear the DNS cache, which is often necessary when troubleshooting connectivity problems or when changes have been made to a domains DNS records. Google Chrome Microsoft Edge FireFox

Flushing the DNS cache is a process that clears stored DNS records on your operating system local machine. This is necessary because the operating system or browser often keeps a cache of recently resolved domain names to speed up future requests. However, if a websites IP address changes, or if there are changes to DNS records, the cached entries can lead to connectivity issues or outdated content. Windows Flushing DNS Cache Commands # Display current DNS cache `Get-DnsClientCache` # Resolve a new domain to create a cache entry Clear the DNS cache Clear-DnsClientCache ![ClearDNS](./Images/Flush/clearDNS.png) ```js # Verify cache is cleared # Register DNS Client with DNS Server `Register-DnsClient` # View Current DNS Server Configuration `Get-DnsClientServerAddress` # View Network IP Configuration `Get-NetIPConfiguration` Linux Flushing DNS Cache Commands # Resolve a new domain to create a cache entry # View Current DNS Server Configuration `nmcli dev show | grep 'IP4.DNS'` # View Network IP Configuration `ip addr show`

Clear-DnsClientCache ![ClearDNS](./Images/Flush/clearDNS.png) ```js # Verify cache is cleared # Register DNS Client with DNS Server `Register-DnsClient` # View Current DNS Server Configuration `Get-DnsClientServerAddress` # View Network IP Configuration `Get-NetIPConfiguration`

An Azure Storage Account is a cloud-based service provided by Microsoft Azure that offers highly available, secure and scalable storage for various types of data It has multiple storage types, including blobs (unstructured data like documents and media), files, queues (message storage) and tables (structured NoSQL data) Azure Storage Accounts are designed to handle a wide range of data storage needs for applications running in the cloud, on-premises, or hybrid environments

Considering selecting an Azure Storage Account for Deciding Factors Reason Storing Large Amounts of Data Ideal for handling large volumes of unstructured data, such as media files, logs, backups and datasets. High Availability and Durability Needs Designed for 99.9% availability and up to 16 nines durability depending on the redundancy option selected. Cost Efficiency Offers multiple storage tiers (hot, cool and archive) to optimize costs based on data access frequency. Flexible Data Access Patterns Supports a wide range of use cases, from high-throughput analytics to low-latency web applications. Integration with Azure Services Seamlessly integrates with other Azure services like Azure Virtual Machines, Azure Functions, Azure App Service and Azure Synapse Analytics. Data Compliance and Security Ensures compliance with various regulations and standards (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA) through features like encryption and data protection.

1. Types of Storage Accounts Type of Storage Account Supported Storage Services Redundancy Options Usage Standard General-Purpose v2 Blob Storage (including Data Lake Storage), Queue Storage, Table Storage, and Azure Files Locally Redundant Storage (LRS) / Geo-Redundant Storage (GRS) / Read-Access Geo-Redundant Storage (RA-GRS) / Zone-Redundant Storage (ZRS) / Geo-Zone-Redundant Storage (GZRS) / Read-Access Geo-Zone-Redundant Storage (RA-GZRS) Standard storage account type for blobs, file shares, queues, and tables. Recommended for most scenarios using Azure Storage. If you want support for Network File System (NFS) in Azure Files, use the premium file shares account type Premium Block Blobs Blob Storage (including Data Lake Storage) LRS / ZRS Premium storage account type for block blobs and append blobs. Recommended for scenarios with high transaction rates or that use smaller objects or require consistently low storage latency. Learn more about example workloads. Premium File Shares Azure Files LRS / ZRS Premium storage account type for file shares only. Recommended for enterprise or high-performance scale applications. Use this account type if you want a storage account that supports both Server Message Block (SMB) and NFS file shares. Premium Page Blobs Page Blobs Only LRS / ZRS Premium storage account type for page blobs only. Learn more about page blobs and their storage accounts. 2. Performance Tiers Factors Reason Hot Tier Optimized for storing data that is accessed or modified frequently. It has the highest storage costs but the lowest access costs. Cool Tier Optimized for storing data that is infrequently accessed or modified. Data should be stored for a minimum of 30 days. It has lower storage costs and higher access costs compared to the hot tier. Cold Tier Optimized for storing data that is rarely accessed or modified but requires fast retrieval. Data should be stored for a minimum of 90 days. It has lower storage costs and higher access costs compared to the cool tier. Archive Tier Optimized for storing data that is rarely accessed and has flexible latency requirements, on the order of hours. Data should be stored for a minimum of 180 days. 3. Redundancy Options Factors Reason Locally Redundant Storage (LRS) Replicates your storage account three times within a single data center in the primary region. Zone-Redundant Storage (ZRS) Replicates your storage account synchronously across three Azure availability zones in the primary region. Geo-Redundant Storage (GRS) Copies data synchronously three times within a single physical location in the primary region using LRS, then copies data asynchronously to a single physical location in the secondary region. Within the secondary region, your data is copied synchronously three times using LRS. Geo-Zone-Redundant Storage (GZRS) Copies your data synchronously across three Azure availability zones in the primary region using ZRS. It then copies your data asynchronously to a single physical location in the secondary region. Within the secondary region, your data is copied synchronously three times using LRS. Read-Access Geo-Redundant Storage (RA-GRS) Same as GRS, with read access to the secondary region. Learn more. 4. Access Controls Factors Reason Network Restrictions Use firewalls, virtual network (VNet) service endpoints, or private endpoints to restrict access. Identity-Based Access Leverage Microsoft Entra ID for secure, managed identity access.

1. Network Security Factors Reason Network Restrictions Use firewall rules, virtual network (VNet) service endpoints to restrict access to the storage account. Private Endpoints Configure private endpoints to ensure that traffic between your VNet and Azure Storage travels over the Azure backbone network. 2. Data Encryption Factors Reason At Rest Azure Storage automatically encrypts data at rest using Storage Service Encryption (SSE) with 256-bit AES encryption. In Transit Use HTTPS to ensure secure data transfer over the network. Customer-Managed Keys Use Azure Key Vault to manage encryption keys. 3. Access Control Factors Reason Shared Access Signatures (SAS) Use SAS tokens to grant limited access to resources without exposing your storage account keys. Note: Always use RBAC-based access to the storage account over SAS. Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) Implement RBAC to control access to resources within the storage account. 4. Data Protection Factors Reason Soft Delete Enable soft delete for blobs and files to recover deleted data. Versioning Enable versioning to keep track of changes to blobs and recover previous versions if needed. 5. Monitoring and Alerts Factors Reason Azure Monitor Use Azure Monitor to track metrics and set up alerts for storage account performance and health. Activity Logs Monitor activity logs to track operations and diagnose issues. 6. Configuration Factors Reason Replication Strategy Choose the appropriate redundancy option based on your disaster recovery and high availability needs. Access Tiers Select the access tier that aligns with your access patterns and cost considerations. Geo-Replication Decide if geo-replication is necessary based on your data residency and compliance requirements. 7. Cost Management Factors Reason Storage Costs Monitor and manage costs based on the storage tier and redundancy option selected. Lifecycle Management Implement lifecycle management policies to move data to lower-cost storage tiers or delete data automatically.

info Learn more about Azure blob storage documentation Learn more about Azure storage RBAC roles assignment Learn more about Azure Identity client library Learn more about Azure storage account encryption Learn more about Azure Storage Account availability & disaster recovery Learn more about Azure storage account lifecycle management policy

Ping is a network utility used to test the reachability of a host on an IP network. It measures the round-trip time for messages sent from the originating host to a destination computer and back. Ping operates by sending ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol) Echo Request messages to the target host and waiting for an Echo Reply. This helps in diagnosing network connectivity issues and determining the performance of the network. Purpose Description Network Troubleshooting Verify if a device or server is reachable. Latency Measurement Measure the time it takes for a packet to travel from the source to the destination and back. Packet Loss Detection Identify any loss of data packets during transmission. Windows Ping Commands # To perform a basic ping test to a target address (IP address or hostname) # To send a specific number of ping requests # To specify the size of the ping packet # To set a timeout period for each ping reply # To continuously ping the destination until stopped manually # To set the TTL value for each ping packet [Time-to-Live value, which shows the number of hops the packet has made] Linux Ping Commands # To perform a basic ping test to a target address (IP address or hostname) # To send a specific number of ping requests # To specify the size of the ping packet # To set a timeout period for each ping reply # To set the TTL value for each ping packet [Time-to-Live value, which shows the number of hops the packet has made]

Traceroute is a network diagnostic tool used to trace the path that packets take from a source to a destination across a network. It provides a map of the route taken by the packets and helps in identifying points of delay or failure in the network path. Traceroute works by sending packets with gradually increasing Time-to-Live (TTL) values and recording the intermediate routers (or hops) that handle these packets. Purpose Description Network Path Analysis Determine the path data packets take to reach a destination. Latency Identification Identify where delays are occurring along the network path. Troubleshooting Diagnose network issues and locate where failures or slowdowns occur. Windows TraceRoute Commands # To perform a basic traceroute to a target address (IP address or hostname) Linux TraceRoute Commands # To perform a basic traceroute to a target address (IP address or hostname)

An IP address can be represented in two primary formats: Dotted-Decimal Notation: Four decimal numbers separated by dots (e.g., 192.168.1.1). Decimal Format: A single decimal number. Converting from dotted-decimal notation to a single decimal number can be useful for various networking tasks, such as IP address calculations and storage. tip For converting IPv4 to Decimal visit IPv4 to Decimal Conversion

CIDR (Classless Inter-Domain Routing) is a way to allocate IP addresses and route IP packets more flexibly than the older class-based addressing. CIDR notation expresses an IP address and its associated network mask in a compact format. For example, 192.168.1.0/24 indicates the IP address 192.168.1.0 with a subnet mask of 255.255.255.0. IP Address: Specifies the network address. Subnet Mask: Determines the network and host portion of the IP address. CIDR Notation: Combines both in a format like IP_address/Prefix_length. tip For converting CIDR to IPv4 visit CIDR to IPv4 Conversion

A netmask, also known as a subnet mask, is a 32-bit number that is used in conjunction with an IP address to specify which part of the address represents the network and which part represents the host. It determines which portion of an IP address is used for the network address and which portion is used for host addresses. Netmasks are essential for routing IP packets between networks and identifying hosts within a subnet. For example, in the IP address 192.168.1.1 with a netmask of 255.255.255.0, the first 24 bits (255.255.255) represent the network address, while the remaining 8 bits (0) represent the host address. Netmask Notation info Decimal Notation: Netmasks are often represented in dotted-decimal format, e.g.,255.255.255.0. CIDR Notation: Alternatively, netmasks are represented in CIDR (Classless Inter-Domain Routing) notation, which specifies the number of bits used for the network portion. For example, 192.168.1.1/24 means that the first 24 bits are used for the network portion. Learn more about Netmask

Ping is a network utility used to test the reachability of a host on an IP network. For IPv6, the ping command is used similarly to IPv4 but with IPv6-specific syntax. Ping utilizes the Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) Echo function as outlined in RFC 792, sending a small packet (64 bytes total) to a specified IP address. Each Ping packet consists of 56 data bytes and 8 bytes of protocol information, with the sending computer waiting for a return packet to assess connectivity. Ping measures the number of hops between two computers and calculates the round-trip time for packets, helping to diagnose network performance. Administrators can use Ping to check name resolution; if a packet returns successfully to an IP address but not to a hostname, there may be issues with the name-to-IP mapping. tip To Learn more about PING, visit Ping

Traceroute is a network diagnostic tool that tracks the path packets take from a source to a destination across an IP network, providing a detailed view of all intermediate routers (hops) along the route. By sending packets with incrementally increasing Time to Live (TTL) values, Traceroute identifies each hop by measuring the round-trip time for responses, which allows users to pinpoint where delays or failures occur in the network. Traceroute is invaluable for troubleshooting network problems, as it reveals not only the final destination but also the path and any bottlenecks that may be affecting the connection. However, its accuracy can be influenced by factors such as firewalls that block ICMP messages or routing policies that affect how packets are handled. tip To Learn more about Trace, visit Trace

CIDR (Classless Inter-Domain Routing) in IPv6 is a method for allocating IP addresses and routing Internet Protocol packets more efficiently than the traditional classful addressing system. It uses a notation that combines the IPv6 address with a prefix length, indicating the number of bits in the address that represent the network portion. For example, 2001:0db8:85a3::/64 signifies that the first 64 bits are allocated for the network, allowing for a vast number of unique host addresses within that subnet. CIDR enables more flexible and efficient allocation of IP addresses, reduces the waste associated with fixed-size address classes, and allows for route aggregation, which simplifies routing tables and enhances routing efficiency. tip To Learn more about CIDR, visit CIDR

Converting from IPv4 to IPv6 involves transitioning an address format that is limited in size to a more expansive one, designed to accommodate the growing number of devices connected to the Internet. Heres an overview of the key concepts and steps involved in this conversion: Understanding Address Formats IPv4: An IPv4 address is a 32-bit number typically represented in decimal format as four octets (e.g., 192.168.1.1). IPv6: An IPv6 address is a 128-bit number represented in hexadecimal format, divided into eight groups of four hexadecimal digits (e.g., 2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334). Address Space Expansion The conversion to IPv6 addresses the limitations of IPv4s 4.3 billion possible addresses by providing a virtually limitless address space, accommodating an estimated 340 undecillion (3.4 x 10^38) unique addresses. Dual Stack Implementation Many networks implement a dual stack approach, allowing devices to support both IPv4 and IPv6 simultaneously. This facilitates gradual migration without requiring an immediate overhaul of existing IPv4 infrastructure. IPv4-Mapped IPv6 Addresses IPv6 provides a way to represent IPv4 addresses within its own format through IPv4-mapped IPv6 addresses. This format is used when an IPv6-capable application needs to communicate with an IPv4 service: Example: An IPv4 address 192.168.1.1 can be represented as ::ffff:192.168.1.1 in IPv6. tip For converting IPv4 to IPv6 visit IPv4 to IPv6 Conversion
To learn more about IP Address Debug Tools, Visit IP Address Guide
documents.u: /docs/Azure360/Azure Best Practices/Debug Tools/IP Address Tools/More Tools

documents.t: Azure Disaster Recovery involves preparing and managing your applications and data to ensure minimal downtime and data loss during unexpected events like natural disasters, hardware failures or cyber-attacks. Azure provides various tools and services to create a robust disaster recovery strategy that ensures business continuity.

Deciding Factors Reason Business Continuity Ensures that your critical applications and data remain available even during disruptions. Minimize Downtime Reduces the amount of time your services are unavailable, maintaining customer trust and satisfaction. Data Protection Safeguards your data against corruption or loss. Regulatory Compliance Helps meet regulatory requirements by providing reliable recovery options. Cost Efficiency Avoids the high costs associated with prolonged outages and data loss.
documents.s: Why Do We Need Disaster Recovery?

documents.t: Azure Site Recovery (ASR)  Provides a comprehensive disaster recovery solution for both on-premises and Azure-based workloads. Replicates your VMs, physical servers and workloads to a secondary location (Azure or another region). Supports both failover (in case of disaster) and failback (returning to the original location once the issue is resolved). Azure Backup  A cloud-based backup solution that protects your data by storing backups in Azure. Supports backing up Azure VMs, SQL databases, file shares and on-premises workloads. Provides multiple retention options and granular recovery points to minimize data loss. Azure Availability Zones  Physically separate data centers within a single Azure region, each with independent power, cooling and networking. Helps ensure high availability and fault tolerance by replicating applications and data across multiple zones. Azure Region Pairs  Azure pairs regions within the same geography to provide replication and failover capabilities. Ensures that at least one region in a pair remains available during planned maintenance or disasters. Enables data residency and compliance by keeping data within the same geography. Geo-Redundant Storage (GRS)  Replicates your data across two geographically separated Azure regions. Provides durability and protection against regional failures. Suitable for scenarios where regulatory requirements or business policies mandate data replication across regions. Azure Traffic Manager  A DNS-based traffic load balancer that directs traffic to healthy service endpoints across different regions or availability zones. Enables automatic failover and ensures that traffic is redirected to the nearest or most responsive location. Useful for multi-region deployments to maintain service availability during regional outages. Azure Load Balancer and Application Gateway  Provides load balancing across multiple instances of your application within a region or across regions. Distributes incoming traffic to multiple back-end resources, improving availability and fault tolerance.
documents.s: Azure Disaster Recovery Tools and Services

documents.t: Define Your Recovery Objectives  Recovery Time Objective (RTO): The maximum acceptable time to restore your application or data after a disruption. Recovery Point Objective (RPO): The maximum acceptable amount of data loss measured in time (e.g., 5 minutes of data). Replicate Resources  Use Azure Site Recovery to replicate your virtual machines and applications to a secondary region or on-premises data center. Set up replication for Azure VMs, on-premises VMs, physical servers and databases. Configure replication policies to define the frequency and retention of replication data. Backup Critical Data  Use Azure Backup to back up critical data regularly. Define backup policies with appropriate retention schedules and recovery points. Verify that backup jobs are completed successfully and test restores periodically. Deploy Across Multiple Zones and Regions  Deploy applications across Azure Availability Zones to ensure high availability within a region. Use Azure Region Pairs to replicate and deploy resources across geographically separated regions. Implement Load Balancing and Traffic Management  Use Azure Traffic Manager to route traffic intelligently across multiple regions or availability zones. Use Azure Load Balancer or Application Gateway to distribute traffic and ensure fault tolerance within regions. Monitor and Test DR Plans  Regularly test your disaster recovery plans by performing failover drills using Azure Site Recovery. Monitor DR-related metrics (e.g., replication health, backup status) in Azure Monitor or Log Analytics. Continuously refine and update your DR strategy based on testing results and changing business requirements.

info Learn more about Azure Site Recovery Documentation Learn more about Azure Backup Documentation Learn more about Azure Availability Zones Learn more about Azure Traffic Manager Documentation Learn more about Geo-Redundant Storage Learn more about Azure reliability Documentation
documents.s: How to Use Azure Disaster Recovery

documents.t: Azure provides four levels of management infrastructure scopes: Management Groups Subscriptions Resource Groups Resources

Deciding Factors Reason Azure policies, role-based access control (RBAC) and compliance To apply and enforce Azure policies, role-based access control (RBAC) and compliance standards consistently across subscriptions. Streamline subscriptions Group subscriptions to streamline billing, reporting and cost management, making it easier to track cloud spending.
documents.s: Deciding factors for Management Groups Scope

documents.t: Deciding Factors Reason Track and manage costs Track and manage costs for specific projects by grouping resources under a subscription for billing purposes. Different payment methods Use different payment methods for different subscriptions, which is useful for separating costs by client or project. Resource quotas and limits Enforce resource quotas and limits to control usage and costs within specific projects, ensuring resources are allocated appropriately. Security boundaries Create distinct security boundaries for different projects or teams by isolating their resources in separate subscriptions. Different environments Use separate subscriptions for different environments (Dev, QA, Staging, Prod) for clear separation needs and to manage subscription resource quota limits.

Deciding Factors Reason Group related resources Group related resources (e.g., VMs, databases, storage accounts) that share the same lifecycle, such as a specific project or development environments. Manage and deploy resources collectively Manage and deploy resources collectively For example, apply tags, access controls, or policies to all resources in the group simultaneously. Assign role-based access control (RBAC) Assign role-based access control (RBAC) to a resource group to limit who can manage the resources within it. Different environments Use separate resource groups for different environments (Dev, QA, Staging, Prod) for centralized billing under a single subscription.
documents.s: Deciding factors for Resource Groups Scope

documents.t: Azure Deployment Automation focuses on automating the provisioning, configuration and deployment of resources in a consistent, repeatable and reliable manner. It helps eliminate manual deployment processes, reduces the risk of errors and speeds up the release cycles.

Deciding Factors Reason Consistency and Reliability Ensures consistent deployment processes, minimizing human error. Speed Accelerates deployment timelines by automating repetitive tasks. Scalability Easily scales deployments across multiple environments (development, testing, production). Cost Efficiency Reduces costs associated with manual interventions and downtime.
documents.s: Why Do We Need Deployment Automation?

documents.t: Azure Resource Manager (ARM) Templates  ARM templates are JSON files that define the resources and configurations needed for your Azure deployment. Supports Infrastructure as Code (IaC), enabling versioning, reuse and automation of your Azure environments. Ideal for automating the deployment of complex environments with multiple resources (e.g., virtual machines, databases, networks). Azure Blueprints  Azure Blueprints enable you to define a repeatable set of Azure resources and policies that can be deployed together. Useful for enforcing compliance and standardizing deployments across different environments.
info Learn more about Azure Resource Manager Templates Learn more about Azure Blueprints

Azure Monitoring is a set of services and tools provided by Microsoft Azure to monitor, diagnose and optimize the performance, availability and health of your applications and infrastructure. Azure Monitoring provides real-time visibility into the operational status and performance of your Azure resources, applications and services.

Factors Description Ensure Availability Monitor resources to ensure they are available and performing as expected. Improve Performance Identify and resolve performance bottlenecks in your applications and infrastructure. Troubleshoot Issues Quickly detect and diagnose problems, reducing downtime and improving response times. Maintain Compliance Monitor compliance with internal and external standards and policies. Optimize Costs Identify underutilized resources or areas where cost savings can be achieved. Automate Responses Use monitoring data to trigger automated actions, such as scaling out resources or restarting services.

Azure Monitor Core Monitoring Service Provides a unified monitoring solution for Azure resources. Collects metrics and logs, provides alerts and integrates with other monitoring tools and services. Azure Application Insights Application Performance Management (APM) service within Azure Monitor that helps monitor the performance and usage of web applications. Provides insights into application performance, exceptions, request rates, response times and dependencies. Azure Log Analytics Log Management and Analysis service collects and analyzes log data from various sources, including Azure resources, on-premises systems and third-party services. Provides powerful querying capabilities to analyze log data for troubleshooting and auditing. Azure Service Health Service Health Monitoring that provides personalized alerts and guidance when Azure service issues affect your resources. Keeps you informed about planned maintenance, outages and other Azure service incidents. Azure Network Watcher Network Monitoring and Diagnostics that helps you monitor and diagnose network issues, such as latency, packet loss and connectivity problems. Provides tools like Network Performance Monitor, Connection Monitor and IP Flow Verify. Azure Security Center Security Monitoring Tool that provides unified security management and advanced threat protection across hybrid cloud workloads. Continuously monitors the security posture of your Azure resources and provides recommendations to enhance security. Azure Sentinel Cloud-Native SIEM(Security Information and Event Management) tool that provides intelligent security analytics and threat intelligence across the enterprise. Integrates with Azure Monitor and other security solutions to provide a centralized view of security threats.

Deciding Factors Reason Azure Monitor Use for monitoring all types of Azure resources (e.g., VMs, databases, networks) to get a comprehensive overview of the cloud environment. Azure Application Insights Use when you need to monitor web applications' performance, detect anomalies and gain insights into user behavior. Azure Log Analytics Use for analyzing log data from various sources for auditing, compliance, or troubleshooting purposes. Azure Service Health Use to stay informed about Azure service issues, planned maintenance and outages that may affect your resources. Azure Network Watcher Use to monitor and diagnose network performance issues, such as latency or connectivity problems. Azure Security Center Use it to monitor and enhance the security posture of your Azure environment and get recommendations for improvement. Azure Sentinel Use when you need a centralized view of security threats and advanced threat detection capabilities.

info Learn more about Azure Monitor Documentation Learn more about Azure Application Insights Documentation Learn more about Azure Log Analytics Documentation Learn more about Azure Service Health Documentation Learn more about Azure Network Watcher Documentation Learn more about Azure Security Center Documentation Learn more about Azure Sentinel Documentation
documents.s: How to Use Azure Monitoring Services

documents.t: Azure OpenAI Service provides access to OpenAI's advanced language models, including the GPT series (like GPT-3 and GPT-4), Codex, and other state-of-the-art AI models hosted on Azure. With this service, developers can integrate natural language understanding, text generation, and other AI capabilities into their applications, unlocking powerful tools for automating tasks, enhancing productivity, and creating rich user experiences.

Factors Reason Content Generation Automatically generate text content like articles, blogs, or product descriptions based on provided input. Natural Language Processing (NLP) Implement NLP tasks like sentiment analysis, summarization, translation, and text completion. Code Automation Use Codex to generate code snippets, perform debugging, or provide coding suggestions in various programming languages. Customer Support Build AI-powered chatbots for answering queries, providing support, and enhancing customer interaction. Data Analysis Analyze large volumes of text-based data, extracting insights and performing automated document processing.
documents.s: When to use Azure Open AI Services

documents.t: Additional Resources For detailed information on Azure Open AI Services, please refer to the official Microsoft documentation: Azure Open AI Services Overview Create a project using AI Studio Create Azure AI services resource
documents.s: How to use Azure Open AI Services

documents.t: The Azure OpenAI Service is offered in specific Azure regions, allowing users to deploy their AI solutions closer to their target audience, which enhances latency and performance. Not all models may be available in all regions, so it's important to verify availability. tip Azure OpenAI Service is not yet available in India, but it is accessible in regions such as the East US and West Europe. This means users in India may need to deploy their applications in other supported regions. For the most current region availability, you can refer to the Azure OpenAI Region Availability.

Model Selection in Azure OpenAI Service allows you to choose from a variety of models, each tailored to specific tasks. The most advanced models like GPT-4 are suited for complex natural language processing, while Codex specializes in code generation. You can select a model based on your application's requirements, whether it's for generating text, analyzing sentiment or automating programming tasks.
info Learn more about Prompt Engineering Learn more about Model Fine Tuning Learn more about Codex for Code Generation
documents.s: Learn more about Azure Open AI Services

documents.t: A good name for a resource helps to quickly identify its type, its associated workload, its environment and the Azure region where it runs. To achieve this, names should follow a consistent naming convention. Use lowercase letters: Keep all resource names in lowercase to avoid confusion. Use hyphens (-): Separating words with hyphens improves readability. Be concise: Use short, meaningful names that convey the resource's purpose. Include resource type identifiers: Include a short identifier for the resource type to avoid confusion.

info Azure resources must follow the below recommended naming convention. Any deviation from the best practice must be documented. [TYPE]-[ORGANIZATION]-[ENVIRONMENT]-[REGION]-[FUNCTION]-[INSTANCE-NUMBER]
Short abbreviation for the resource types. Use the given reference to find the abbreviation for all Azure resources.
This is an optional field to include for Azure resources. Use this naming convention for subscription scope, resource groups scope and global services like storage accounts & key vaults.
Identifies the environment and should be at most 4 characters. Recommended names are dev, qa, stag, plat and prod, which denote development, testing, staging, platform and production environments.

Identifies the Azure region where the resource is deployed. Should be at most 3 characters. Examples: wus (West US), eus (East US), cin (Central India). Reference list for the two-letter country codes.
Identifies application name, function, or description. Should be at most 10 characters. Examples: frontend, backend, vectordb.

This is an optional field and should be added to the function name. Consider using when a resource group consists of multiple resources for the same type of workload. Example: A resource group using multiple VMs for the same workload for high availability reasons should use an instance number for naming such resources.

Example Resource Group Naming: rg-sol-dev-cin-stellar Name Identifier Description rg TYPE Denotes Resource Group dev ENVIRONMENT Development Environment cin REGION Location Central India stellar FUNCTION Project Name - INSTANCE NUMBER Not applicable Example Resource Naming: ase-dev-cin-frontend-01 Name Identifier Description ase TYPE Denotes App Service resource - ORGANIZATION Not needed since resource group already covers the organization name dev ENVIRONMENT Development Environment cin REGION Location Central India frontend FUNCTION Functionality of the App Service 01 INSTANCE NUMBER Instance number of the application. Only required for applications with similar functionality

Let's consider a storage account with containers. The container names don't need to include environment or region details, as these are covered by the parent context. The sub-resources of a parent resource do not adhere completely to the naming convention. Consider the following sub-resources: Containers, Blobs, Tables in the Storage Account Subnets in an Azure Virtual Network Secrets or certificates in an Azure Key Vault Topics or queues in an Azure Service Bus Consider a virtual network named vnet-dev-eus-stellar that has a subnet for placing Azure Virtual Machines. The subnet could be named snet-vm or snet-virtual-machine. tip Special Cases Some resources have character set or length restrictions in their names. Use a separate naming convention for resources with restrictions. Dont have hyphens in the name for character set restrictions. Example: stcdevcinstellar (no delimiter allowed for storage account names)

Some resources have character set or length restrictions in their names. Use a separate naming convention for resources with restrictions. Dont have hyphens in the name for character set restrictions. Example: stcdevcinstellar (no delimiter allowed for storage account names)
info Before deploying resources in Azure, it's essential to evaluate key factors related to regions, availability zones and region pairs to understand when to use these features.

Deciding Factors Reason Latency and Performance Selecting a region close to your users minimizes latency and improves performance. Compliance and Data Residency Certain industries and countries have regulations & laws requiring data to be stored within specific geographical boundaries. Service Availability Not all Azure services or VM types are available in every region. Consider Service Availability for service availability. Cost Efficiency Azure pricing varies by region. Choosing a region with lower costs for resources can reduce your operational expenses.

Deciding Factors Reason High Availability Requirements Use Availability Zones if the application needs to be highly available and resilient to datacenter-level failures. Mission-Critical Workloads For applications that are critical to business operations and cannot tolerate downtime, Availability Zones provide an added layer of redundancy and reliability. Data Protection and Redundancy If data needs to be protected against hardware failures or natural disasters, deploying resources across Availability Zones helps ensure data protection. Minimizing Latency During Failover If the application needs to failover quickly with minimal latency, using Availability Zones within the same region ensures fast recovery times compared to cross-region failover.

Deciding Factors Reason Disaster Recovery Use region pairs to ensure business continuity in the event of a major disaster. If one region in the pair is affected, services can failover to the other region. Geographical Redundancy When you need redundancy across a large geographical area to mitigate risks associated with regional outages, such as natural disasters or widespread network failures. High Service Availability If an application or service requires high availability with automatic failover, region pairs help to ensure that your service remains accessible even if one region experiences an outage.

This section outlines the best practices and conventions that must be followed for projects deployed in Azure. Any deviations from the recommended best practices must be documented and communicated with stakeholders. info It is highly recommended to read this entire document before getting started with project deployment. Readers of this document must be familiar with Azure fundamentals (AZ-900) or have equivalent hands-on experience in Azure.

Gather the requirements for the project & choose considerations based on the below-mentioned factors. Purpose of the Checklist This checklist won't give concrete answers for your project, because it depends majorly on the project requirements. Instead this checklist creates an awareness of all the different aspects that need to be considered for Azure solutions. Download Download as PDF Download as CSV
